prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Relationship to other forms of transfer and consolidation—Comparison to class action treatment

para.paratext: Transfer of multiple actions under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is significantly different from certification of an action or actions to proceed as a class or classes under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23. Class actions exist as a form of permissive joinder of parties under the federal rules. Although the court becomes involved in class action decisions, actions are not certified as class actions unless some party (usually a plaintiff) seeks that treatment by commencing a class action suit or making such a claim in a similar pleading.

The Panel has recognized that the questions of class action certification and § 1407 transfer are sufficiently unrelated that the refusal of a trial court to certify a class action does not affect the Panel's consideration of transfer under the statute.[1] The Panel gives consideration to the potential that conflicting class actions may exist, and is likely to order transfer to place such potentially conflicting actions before a single judge.[2]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286, 287 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
